name: 1598_C. Delete Two Elements
description:
Monocarp has got an array a consisting of n integers. Let's denote k as the mathematic mean of these elements (note that it's possible that k is not an integer). 

The mathematic mean of an array of n elements is the sum of elements divided by the number of these elements (i. e. sum divided by n).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k.

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
repair_prompt:
Monocarp's array a consists of n integers. Let's denote k as the average value of these elements (note that k might not be an integer).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k, which is the average of an array with n items, calculated as the total of those items divided by how many there are (i.e., sum divided by n).

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Assume that the array contains at least two elements.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Monocarp's array a consists of n integers. Let's denote k as the average value of these elements (note that k might not be an integer). Monocarp aims to remove two elements from a in such a way that the average of the remaining elements (n - 2) is still equal to k, the average of an array with n items, which is calculated by dividing the total sum of items by the number of items.

Your task is to determine the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) where deleting the elements at these positions maintains the average value of the remaining (n - 2) elements as k, the average of the original array a with n elements. It can be assumed that the array contains a minimum of two elements.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

-------

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

completion:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the average value (k) of the array
    k = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs of positions
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of remaining elements after deleting elements at positions i and j
            remaining_sum = sum(arr) - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average of remaining elements
            remaining_avg = remaining_sum / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average of remaining elements is equal to k
            if remaining_avg == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions for each testcase
    print(pairs_count)

main()
completions:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the average value of the array
    k = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs
    pairs = 0
    
    # Create a dictionary to store the frequency of each element
    freq = {}
    for num in arr:
        freq[num] = freq.get(num, 0) + 1
    
    # Iterate over all unique elements in the array
    for num in set(arr):
        # Calculate the total sum if both occurrences of the element are removed
        total = sum(arr) - num * 2
        
        # Calculate the average value of the remaining elements
        avg = total / (n - 2)
        
        # Check if the average value is equal to k
        if avg == k:
            # Calculate the number of ways to choose 2 occurrences of the element
            pairs += freq[num] * (freq[num] - 1) // 2
    
    # Output the total number of pairs for each testcase
    print(pairs)

main()

# Function to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] that satisfy the condition
def calculate_pairs(t, testcases):
    result = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = testcases[_][0]
        arr = testcases[_][1]
        
        total_sum = sum(arr)
        k = total_sum / n
        
        count = 0
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i+1, n):
                if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == k:
                    count += 1
        
        result.append(count)
    
    return result

# Input
t = int(input())
testcases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    testcases.append((n, arr))

# Calculate and output the result
result = calculate_pairs(t, testcases)
for res in result:
    print(res)

main()

Round_0.code:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the sum of the array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    
    # Calculate the average value of the array
    k = total_sum / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of pairs
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of the remaining elements after removing elements at positions i and j
            remaining_sum = total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average of the remaining elements
            remaining_avg = remaining_sum / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average of the remaining elements is equal to k
            if remaining_avg == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Output the total number of pairs for each testcase
    print(pairs_count)

Round_0.code:
# Function to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] that satisfy the condition
def calculate_pairs(t, testcases):
    result = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n = testcases[_][0]
        arr = testcases[_][1]
        
        total_sum = sum(arr)
        k = total_sum / n
        
        count = 0
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i+1, n):
                if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == k:
                    count += 1
        
        result.append(count)
    
    return result

# Input
t = int(input())
testcases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n = int(input())
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    testcases.append((n, arr))

# Calculate and output the result
result = calculate_pairs(t, testcases)
for res in result:
    print(res)

# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the average value of the array
    total_sum = sum(arr)
    k = total_sum / n
    
    # Identify pairs of positions where removing elements maintains the average value
    count_pairs = 0
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            if (total_sum - arr[i] - arr[j]) / (n - 2) == k:
                count_pairs += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions for each testcase
    print(count_pairs)

# [edge case] 
    Input:
    4

    8 8 8 8
    Output:
    6
    Explanation:
    In this case, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

    Input:
    3
    50 20 10
    Output:
    0
    Explanation:
    There is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

    Input:
    5
    1 4 7 3 5
    Output:
    2
    Explanation:
    It is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.

Round_0.code:
# Read the number of testcases
t = int(input())

# Iterate over each testcase
for _ in range(t):
    # Read the number of elements in the array
    n = int(input())
    
    # Read the sequence of integers in the array
    arr = list(map(int, input().split()))
    
    # Calculate the average value (k) of the array
    k = sum(arr) / n
    
    # Initialize a counter for pairs of positions
    pairs_count = 0
    
    # Iterate over all pairs of positions [i, j]
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(i+1, n):
            # Calculate the sum of remaining elements after deleting elements at positions i and j
            remaining_sum = sum(arr) - arr[i] - arr[j]
            
            # Calculate the average of remaining elements
            remaining_avg = remaining_sum / (n - 2)
            
            # Check if the average of remaining elements is equal to k
            if remaining_avg == k:
                pairs_count += 1
    
    # Print the number of pairs of positions for each testcase
    print(pairs_count)

    # Print the number of pairs of positions for each testcase
    print(pairs_count)

prompt:
Monocarp's array a consists of n integers. Let's denote k as the average value of these elements (note that k might not be an integer).

Monocarp wants to delete exactly two elements from a so that the mathematic mean of the remaining (n - 2) elements is still equal to k, which is the average of an array with n items, calculated as the total of those items divided by how many there are (i.e., sum divided by n).

Your task is to calculate the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a). Assume that the array contains at least two elements.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input


4
4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains one integer n (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) — the number of elements in the array.

The second line contains a sequence of integers a_1, a_2, ..., a_n (0 ≤ a_i ≤ 10^{9}), where a_i is the i-th element of the array.

The sum of n over all testcases doesn't exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.

Output

Print one integer — the number of pairs of positions [i, j] (i < j) such that if the elements on these positions are deleted, the mathematic mean of (n - 2) remaining elements is equal to k (that is, it is equal to the mathematic mean of n elements of the original array a).

Example

Input

4
8 8 8 8
3
50 20 10
5
1 4 7 3 5
7
1 2 3 4 5 6 7


Output


6
0
2
3

Note

In the first example, any pair of elements can be removed since all of them are equal.

In the second example, there is no way to delete two elements so the mathematic mean doesn't change.

In the third example, it is possible to delete the elements on positions 1 and 3, or the elements on positions 4 and 5.
